  "The current displayed page contains invalid values"

Next, I created a fresh workspace and I created a Dynamic Web Project. In the new workspace, the J2EE Module Dependencies feature works fine.
I am attaching three files from my Dynamic Web Project: .project, .classpath, and org.eclipse.wst.common.component

All of them showing NPE in VirtualResource.java:317
Will WebTools 1.5.4 include a fix for this bug?
Not planned for WTP 1.5.4, it is untargetted.
IMHO, this bug is a showstopper.  How can we increase the priority for this bug?
Sean, i could look at this defect for 1.5.4 but please attach full Web project on which I can  reproduce, the current attachments of .project, .classpath and .component are not sufficient.

I fixed the problem. The problem seems to be the project configuration files/j2ee dependencies. Could be caused by upgrading from wtp 1.0 to 1.5?
I fixed it by creating similar projects in a clean workspace, and then copy all .settings-files, .project and .classpath to the problematic workspace. Had to fix dependencies after that, but now everything is back to normal.
Marking as WONTFIX

I encountered this bug again with Eclipse 3.3RC3 and WebTools 2.0 RC3

I was modifying the J2EE Module Dependencies in my project and everything seems ok at first.  Later, I tried returning to the J2EE Module Dependencies and I got a message box:  "The current displayed page contains invalid values"

Can we re-open this bug?   I don't think I've done anything wrong as a user and Eclipse is not giving me any way to correct the "invalid values"

Created an attachment (id=72103)
Eclipse 3.3RC3 .log file

This is the .log file
Will take a look - but targetting 201
Sean, see my Comment #12

I was able to debug this problem for WebTools 2.0.   This information is probably also applicable for WebTools 1.5.x

My workspace has Dynamic Web projects and Java projects.

"The current displayed page contains invalid values" is trigged by Java projects that do not have the org.eclipse.wst.common.modulecore.ModuleCoreNature nature.

I manually added this line to all .project files in all of my Java projects:

	<nature>org.eclipse.wst.common.modulecore.ModuleCoreNature</nature>

After this change, the error/exception no longer occurs.

Using the debugger, I observed the following:

       //  VirtualResource.java line 317
	moduleCore = StructureEdit.getStructureEditForRead(getProject());

The getStructureEditForRead method returns null when the project does not have 
the org.eclipse.wst.common.modulecore.ModuleCoreNature nature.

VirtualResource assumes that getStructureEditForRead will always return a non-null value.   This seems to be a bad assumption.

I'd like to see better error handling in VirtualResource.java   There should be a better way to inform the user of the problem and assist the user in correcting it.

Sean,
If you create a Java project, you dont see J2EE Module dependencies, the project needs to have WTP metadata(for e.g. .component file), how did you 
create your java projects?

Neeraj,

My Java projects and Web projects were originally created in IBM Websphere Studio 5.1.2    (Note:  Websphere Studio 5.1.2 is based on Eclipse 2.x)

Clearly, my Java projects did not have the WTP metadata because the Java projects were not created in a WTP environment.

Observations:

1) when I checked out my Java projects from my CVS repository, WTP 2.0 did not 
   add the WTP metadata to my projects

2) the NullPointerException can be prevented or trapped. The WTP 2.0 
   environment should be able detect that a Java project is missing
   the WTP metadata

Sean

No, all java projects need not be converted into WTP projects,i still don't understand if it still java project how you are able to see J2EE module dependencies page.

Also i have requested previously  in Comment#12 and comment#18 to attach workspace, that is a must to further work on this defect,

My employer won't allow me to share my workspace. The projects have proprietary code and files.   There are a large number of projects and it would be difficult to extract a smaller subset of projects.

I will try creating a simple set of projects in Websphere Studio and let you know it goes.

Sean
Sean, migration of projects created in WebSphere Studio to WTP is not supported.

Neeraj,

I understand that Websphere Studio project migration is not a feature of WTP.

However, I'd like to see better error handling in WTP.  WTP's code is throwing a NullPointerException and no way for the user to understand what is going wrong.

I'd like to see the WTP detect when the project metadata is missing and (perhaps) display a meaning message to the user.

The current behavior in WTP 2.0 is unfriendly for end users.

Sean

I also encountered this problem. Per Comment #24 it sounds like it may never be fixed even though it ironically only affects customers who have been loyal and used their legacy products (i.e,, WSAD 5.1). Given that, the workaround in Comment #19 is right on the money. ...added this line to all .project files in all of my Java projects: org.eclipse.wst.common.modulecore.ModuleCoreNature Please be SURE to add it to ALL of your Java projects in the Workspace.

This can still occur using Eclipse 3.3.1 and WTP 2.0.1, and without doing any migration from WSAD or whatever. I had a workspace that worked without problems and was fully created using Eclipse 3.3. After trying to use the Tomcat 6 container and switching it to "publish from workspace" I could no longer open the J2EE properties page. I had to edit 75 .project files to get it to work again. 8-(

I find it rather incomprehensible that a bug causes a complete workspace to become unavailable simply because an error causes that a config dialog does not show again. If there ARE problems in the config it's OK to report the problem but disabling the dialog means no-one can fix the problem ever without resorting to manually editing the buggy WTP publishing files.

If a problem is found fix it; if that cannot be done restore to a state where at least the configuration can be edited, even if that means you have to specify the j2ee dependencies again.

This said I really /really/ hope that WTP 3.0 finally delivers something that is even remotely useful as a web publishing framework. The current implementation is one big bug and unusable for any big workspace with multiple dependent projects.

I work with a team of 15, and we have some 25 projects. This bug is happening to several of us. The process of completely rebuilding the workspaces is a complete drag. Anyone know what element in the workspace config might be getting corrupted?

Some of the projects were created with whatever was current 2 years ago, some of the projects are new, they are all checked in and out of svn.

It would appear that this is not a config of the project problem, but some config having to do with the local workspace.

This bug is really slowing us down currently. Any help with a work around would be appreciated.

Did you add the line referred to in comment #19 and comment #26?

That worked around the problem for me.

With regards to comment #24, perhaps this is caused by migrating "old" pre-WST web projects from IBM's WSAD 5.x or RAD 6.x.  In my limited dealings with them, the Eclipse team seems loathe to harden their tooling to handle malformed projects generated by these legacy IBM products.  

For IBM customers using RAD 7, that puts the burden on IBM to do a better job of migrating "legacy" projects so that they run work with the WST, which it now uses.  

Folks who left the IBM fray but want to use "legacy" projects with WST, you may be SOL.
